content.text: Note: These are the only two concepts that we are going to focus on.
A variable is a name given to a piece of memory in the computer where a program stores information. It stores values such as numbers and names that will be used at a later stage.
Think of a variable as a container or a basket that is storing a fruit in it. For example:

items: The whole basket is the variable.
"Banana" is the value stored in the variable.
"Fruitbasket" is the variable name.
Name: A unique identifier for the memory location (e.g., Fruitbasket).
Value: The actual data stored (e.g., Banana).
Data Type: Defines the kind of data the variable holds (e.g., integer for whole numbers, string for text, float for numbers with decimals).

content.text: You create a variable by giving it a unique name, the type of data it will store, and you can give it a value it will store.
Create a variable to store integer numbers.
Create a variable to store integer number 20.

DECLARE number AS INTEGER
SET number to 20

items: DECLARE means create a variable.
number is the variable name.
INTEGER means the variable will store whole numbers.
SET assigns a value to the variable.

content.text: An if-statement is a concept in programming that we use to make decisions in a program.

items: The keyword: IF a condition is true, THEN do something.
A condition: The if statement evaluates an expression using comparison operators like ==, >, or < that results in a boolean value: either true or false.

content.text:
IF Light is green THEN
    Cross the road
END IF
The program checks the condition ("Light is green"). If the condition is true, the action ("Cross the road") is executed.
Let's check if a student can get an ID.

IF Age >= 16 THEN
    DISPLAY "You can get an ID"
END IF

items: IF -> keyword
Age >= 16 -> this is the condition
DISPLAY "You can get an ID" -> this is the action
END IF -> end of the IF-statement

content.text: Let's check if the student has passed.

IF exam >= 50 THEN
    DISPLAY "The student passed"
END IF

items: IF -> keyword that checks the condition
exam >= 50 -> this is the condition
THEN -> tells the computer what to do
DISPLAY "The student passed" -> this is the action
END IF -> the end of the IF-statement

content.text: So what do you do if the condition is false?
Another action must be taken if the condition is false. To do that, you add the keyword ELSE.

IF Light is green THEN
    Cross the road
ELSE
    Wait
END IF
If the condition is true, the action ("Cross the road") is executed. If the condition is false, the action ("Wait") will be executed.
Let's check if the student passed or failed.

IF Mark >= 50 THEN
    DISPLAY "The student passed"
ELSE
    DISPLAY "The student failed"
END IF

items: IF -> checks a condition
Mark >= 50 -> this is the condition
THEN -> tells the computer what to do
DISPLAY "The student passed" -> action when the condition is true
ELSE -> what to do if the condition is false
DISPLAY "The student failed" -> action when the condition is false
END IF -> the end of the IF-statement
